title: III% (Three Percenters)
description: Anti-government militia movement symbol. Represents the 'three percent' who would resist tyranny.
historicalContext: Based on the myth that only 3% of American colonists actively fought in the Revolutionary War.
cooptation: Used by anti-government and militia groups to justify armed resistance against perceived government overreach.

contextGuidance.context: Often seen on flags, clothing, and social media. Associated with anti-government and militia groups.
contextGuidance.guidance: Assess context carefully. May indicate anti-government sentiment or potential for violence.

title: Black Sun (Sonnenrad)
description: Nazi symbol consisting of twelve radial sig runes. Used by white supremacist groups.
historicalContext: Originally a Nazi occult symbol adopted by the SS and used in modern neo-Nazi ideology.
cooptation: Common in white supremacist art, tattoos, and flags.

contextGuidance.context: Used globally by white supremacist movements. Often paired with other hate symbols.
contextGuidance.guidance: Strongly associated with neo-Nazi ideology. Treat with high concern.

title: Odal / Othala Rune
description: Norse rune symbol used by white supremacist groups. Represents heritage and bloodline.
historicalContext: An ancient rune repurposed by Nazi Germany and modern hate groups.
cooptation: Used in racist and nationalist iconography.

contextGuidance.context: May be used innocently in pagan contexts, but often tied to extremist groups.
contextGuidance.guidance: Analyze usage carefully. Look for context clues or group affiliation.

title: Boogaloo (Igloo / Hawaiian)
description: Meme-based movement calling for civil war or violent uprising against the government.
historicalContext: Originated from internet forums promoting violent resistance.
cooptation: Adopted by extremists using Hawaiian shirts and igloo imagery.

contextGuidance.context: Often disguised as satire or humor. Look for coded language.
contextGuidance.guidance: Treat with high caution, especially when linked with weapons or violence references.

description: Numerical code representing '14 Words' and 'Heil Hitler'. Widely used by white supremacists.
historicalContext: Created by David Lane, a white supremacist terrorist.
cooptation: Used in graffiti, tattoos, and usernames.

contextGuidance.context: Almost exclusively a hate symbol when used together.
contextGuidance.guidance: Take seriously. Typically indicates explicit white supremacist belief.

title: Swastika
description: Most widely recognized Nazi symbol. Represents Aryan identity and Nazi ideology.
historicalContext: Ancient symbol misappropriated by Nazi Germany in the 1930s.
cooptation: Used by neo-Nazi and fascist groups worldwide.

contextGuidance.context: Context is crucial. In Western contexts, usually a hate symbol.
contextGuidance.guidance: Treat with extreme caution. Rarely used outside of hate contexts in the West.

title: Molon Labe
description: Ancient Greek phrase meaning 'Come and take [them]'. Used by gun rights advocates.
historicalContext: Phrase attributed to King Leonidas at the Battle of Thermopylae.
cooptation: Used by pro-gun and militia movements as defiance against gun control.

contextGuidance.context: May be used non-violently, but often tied to extreme resistance to authority.
contextGuidance.guidance: Consider alongside other symbols and context.

title: Gadsden Flag
description: Yellow flag with coiled snake and 'Don't Tread on Me'. Originally a symbol of American liberty.
historicalContext: Used during the American Revolution. Re-emerged in libertarian and far-right movements.
cooptation: Used by militia groups, anti-government protests.

contextGuidance.context: May be used innocently or with extremist undertones.
contextGuidance.guidance: Assess intent, especially in group settings or rallies.

title: Tiwaz Rune
description: Norse rune associated with the god Tyr. Misused by Nazi Germany and far-right groups.
historicalContext: Originally symbolized justice and war in Norse mythology.
cooptation: Adopted by SS training schools and neo-Nazi groups.

contextGuidance.context: Used in pagan spirituality, but context matters.
contextGuidance.guidance: Look for affiliations and co-occurring symbols.

title: Don't Tread on Me
description: Popular motto from the American Revolution. Signifies defiance against perceived tyranny.
historicalContext: Associated with early American independence. Re-adopted by modern libertarian and right-wing movements.
cooptation: Used by militia groups and protesters.

contextGuidance.context: Can be benign or extreme depending on usage.
contextGuidance.guidance: Use context to determine risk â€” especially when combined with other symbols.

description: '88' is a coded reference to 'Heil Hitler' (H = 8th letter of the alphabet).
historicalContext: Used in Nazi Germany and revived by neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups.
cooptation: Frequently seen in usernames, graffiti, and tattoos.

contextGuidance.context: Rarely used outside hate contexts. Often hidden in usernames or tattoos.
contextGuidance.guidance: High concern when seen with other hate symbols.

title: 14 Words
description: A white supremacist slogan: 'We must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children.'
historicalContext: Coined by David Lane, a convicted white supremacist terrorist.
cooptation: Used in writings, forums, tattoos, and propaganda.

contextGuidance.context: Clearly linked to white supremacist ideology. Rarely ambiguous.
contextGuidance.guidance: Flag immediately if present. Strong indicator of extremist beliefs.
